SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: What are two main ideas about weightlessness in the text?

A.Choice: It is easy to handle and makes the room seem bigger.

B.Choice: It makes bones heavy and causes the head to swell.

C.Choice: It is uncomfortable for the body and upsets the stomach.

D.Choice: It reroutes the flow of blood and puts the heart in danger.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Why does the author use the word NOT in paragraph 2?

A.Choice: The author is trying to make sure the reader understands the point.

B.Choice: The author is showing that some information is untrue.

C.Choice: The author is using quotes from a space tourist.

D.Choice: The author is disagreeing with the reader.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: Which statement summarizes the author’s view on weightlessness?

A.Choice: “In fact, everything is fun, nothing is hard.”

B.Choice: “ ‘Living in space is like having a different life, living in a different world.’ ”

C.Choice: “If you turn yourself upside down, the ceiling becomes the floor.”

D.Choice: “In low gravity, you have to learn new ways to eat.”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: What is the meaning of the word “rerouted” in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: pumping extra blood

B.Choice: going the same way

C.Choice: changing the direction

D.Choice: hanging upside down

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: How does the lack of gravity in space affect the bones?

A.Choice: The bones stretch and bend easier.

B.Choice: The bones break while in space.

C.Choice: The bones become stronger.

D.Choice: The bones become thin and spongy.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: How might astronauts in space prepare for the return to Earth?

A.Choice: by performing somersaults and flying around

B.Choice: by learning how to care for themselves when feeling sick

C.Choice: by doing exercises to strengthen bones and muscles

D.Choice: by growing taller and getting flabby

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: What is meant by the phrase “nooks and crannies” in paragraph 12?

A.Choice: outer space

B.Choice: small places

C.Choice: on the ceiling

D.Choice: out in the open

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which statement summarizes the text?

A.Choice: After adjusting, the astronauts enjoy some of the benefits of weightlessness.

B.Choice: At first, many astronauts find weightlessness to be fun and easy.

C.Choice: Usually, astronauts take a one-year trip to Mars.

D.Choice: In space, astronauts’ bodies have to adapt to Earth’s gravity.

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Which statement explains why saguaro ribs and creosote branches are important for creating saguaro syrup?

A.Choice: Saguaro fruit are peeled using saguaro ribs and creosote branches.

B.Choice: Kukuipads are created with saguaro ribs and creosote branches.

C.Choice: Fruit from creosote branches and saguaro ribs are used to make the syrup.

D.Choice: Saguaro ribs and creosote branches are ingredients needed to create the syrup.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Based on paragraphs 4 and 5, why are creosote branches used at the top of a kukuipad?

A.Choice: Creosote branches are straight and light, making it easy to spear fruit at the top of a saguaro cactus.

B.Choice: Creosote branches are thick and heavy, making it easy to push fruit from the top of a saguaro cactus.

C.Choice: Creosote branches are bright red and freckled, making it easy to see them at the top of a saguaro cactus.

D.Choice: Creosote branches are sturdy and durable, making it easy to prod fruit from the top of a saguaro cactus.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which detail reveals how the Tohono O’odham feel about the land?

A.Choice: Gina shows the harvesters how to make kukuipad.

B.Choice: Gina and Angie add water to the saguaro fruit and boil it.

C.Choice: Gina tells the harvesters to leave the first fruit at the base of the saguaro.

D.Choice: Gina brings a square cloth to strain the syrup before boiling it again.

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does the word “summon” mean in paragraph 8?

A.Choice: bring forth

B.Choice: send away

C.Choice: catch

D.Choice: stop

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: Which step comes after placing the peel at the base of the saguaro?

A.Choice: Bring out a square cloth to strain the mixture.

B.Choice: Return the hot juice to the cleaned pot to boil a second time.

C.Choice: Scoop the fruit into buckets and avoid the spines that cling to the peel.

D.Choice: Nudge the saguaro fruit loose and put into buckets.

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What does the word “flecked” mean in paragraph 9?

A.Choice: striped

B.Choice: dotted

C.Choice: disguised

D.Choice: wrapped

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: What is the meaning of “strain” as it is used in paragraph 10?

A.Choice: pass through a filter

B.Choice: injure a body part

C.Choice: painful effort

D.Choice: make great demands

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: How are the harvesting of saguaro fruit and the creation of saguaro syrup similar?

A.Choice: Both require creosote branches and boiling water to reach the desired result.

B.Choice: Both require inexperience and good fortune to reach the desired result.

C.Choice: Both require kukuipads and large pots to reach the desired result.

D.Choice: Both require patience and persistence to reach the desired result.

SubTopics: Determine two or more main ideas of a text and explain how they are supported by key details; summarize the text.
Content: Which two details from the text support the main ideas?

A.Choice: A terrarium is easy to create, and terrariums were first named Wardian cases.

B.Choice: A terrarium gets its name from the Greek word terra, and a terrarium is in a clear glass or plastic container.

C.Choice: A terrarium is used as a home-decorating item, and Wardian cases replaced greenhouses in the Victorian era.

D.Choice: A terrarium is a tiny ecosystem inside a container, and Dr. Ward accidentally discovered the terrarium.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which describes a good terrarium?

A.Choice: a new, clean container

B.Choice: a large, clear container

C.Choice: a recycled, used container

D.Choice: an expensive, fancy container

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What is the meaning of “transparent” in paragraph 5?

A.Choice: unbreakable

B.Choice: gigantic

C.Choice: clear

D.Choice: open

SubTopics: Explain the relationships or interactions between two or more individuals, events, ideas, or concepts in a historical, scientific, or technical text based on specific information in the text.
Content: How did Dr. Ward’s study of the sphinx moth affect his decision to write a book?

A.Choice: His studies of the sphinx moth caused his accidental discovery of the terrarium.

B.Choice: His studies of the sphinx moth became popular during the Victorian era.

C.Choice: His studies of the sphinx moth were published in the book.

D.Choice: His studies of the sphinx moth were performed inside Wardian cases.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What happened to Dr. Ward’s experimental terrarium?

A.Choice: It became too dry.

B.Choice: It required much care.

C.Choice: It lasted for years.

D.Choice: It bloomed too often.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Ideas & Analysis
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: For what reason does the author include information on the origin of the terrarium in the text?

A.Choice: to help the reader understand its history

B.Choice: to provide directions about how to create it

C.Choice: to show its importance in home decorating

D.Choice: to tell the background of its inventor

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What is the meaning of the word exotic in paragraph 8?

A.Choice: familiar

B.Choice: unusual

C.Choice: local

D.Choice: unsteady

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: How did terrariums help plant collectors?

A.Choice: Plant collectors could learn to build greenhouses.

B.Choice: Terrariums allowed plant collectors to grow gardens.

C.Choice: Plant collectors could experiment with saltwater and freshwater.

D.Choice: Terrariums allowed plant collectors to safely travel with plants.

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator’s or speaker’s point of view influences how events are described.
Content: Which quote supports Annabel Lee’s point of view that life in her house is like a case waiting to be solved?

A.Choice: “I’m working the day shift out of headquarters.”

B.Choice: “Leap downstairs, taking the steps two by two, to the laundry room.”

C.Choice: “I lick the tip of my pen, like they do on cop shows.”

D.Choice: “I find him at the kitchen table, reading the paper and sipping coffee.”

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: How does the dialogue in paragraphs 12–19 compare Annabel Lee and her brother, John?

A.Choice: It underlines the fact that Annabel Lee deeply admires her brother, John.

B.Choice: It creates a sense of their relationship and shows that John and Annabel Lee think alike.

C.Choice: It underlines the fact that Annabel Lee and John are incapable of getting along.

D.Choice: It creates a sense of their relationship and implies that John often tolerates Annabel Lee’s behavior.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What can be inferred from the quote below in paragraph 17?
:ibox:“ ‘It’s a sock, see. What do you think it looks like? An elephant?’ ”

A.Choice: John appreciates his sister’s help.

B.Choice: John thinks his sister has the sock.

C.Choice: John is bothered by his sister’s help.

D.Choice: John does not think he will find his sock.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: Which statement describes how Mom feels when Annabel asks her about the missing sock?

A.Choice: She is upset that the children do not help with the chores.

B.Choice: She is grateful that Annabel likes to solve mysteries.

C.Choice: She is dismayed that Jack is not dressed yet.

D.Choice: She is worried that it will never be found.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which quote suggests that the mother feels resentment?

A.Choice: “ ‘Oh, you found it? John was looking for it. Get dressed for school, dear, or you’ll miss the bus.’ ”

B.Choice: “ ‘If you and your brother would offer to help once in a while . . .’ ”

C.Choice: “Her eyes narrow in The Mom Look.”

D.Choice: “ ‘What’s that?’ Mom comes downstairs—every hair in place—and pours herself a cup of coffee.”

SubTopics: Determine and/or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 5 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies: context clues, word parts, word relationships, and reference materials.
Content: What is the meaning of the word “triumphantly” in paragraph 32?

A.Choice: mysteriously

B.Choice: successfully

C.Choice: pleasantly

D.Choice: harshly

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What inference can be made from the question “Have what?” in paragraph 34?

A.Choice: Annabel’s brother lost the other sock.

B.Choice: Annabel’s mom lost the other sock.

C.Choice: Annabel’s dad lost the other sock.

D.Choice: Annabel lost the other sock.

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator’s or speaker’s point of view influences how events are described.
Content: How does Annabel Lee’s detective approach influence how the events in the story are told?

A.Choice: It creates a methodical and orderly structure for the plot.

B.Choice: It adds a sense of surprise and disappointment to the plot.

C.Choice: It provides a framework of frustration for the family.

D.Choice: It offers an inside look at the disorganization in the family.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which theme do key details in the selection support?

A.Choice: Generosity is rewarded.

B.Choice: Do not judge a book by its cover.

C.Choice: People should overcome their fear.

D.Choice: Family is most important.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Where did Antonio get ideas for his “pictures” as a little boy?

A.Choice: from rich people

B.Choice: from other famous artists

C.Choice: from stories his grandmother told him

D.Choice: from what he saw his grandfather doing

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, recognizing specific word choices that contribute to meaning and tone.
Content: What does the phrase “spread the table” mean in paragraph 8?

A.Choice: to separate the table

B.Choice: to make the table cleaner

C.Choice: to make the table larger

D.Choice: to decorate the table

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which event caused Antonio to create the sculpture?

A.Choice: The stonecutter could not fix the sculpture.

B.Choice: The servants dared him to make the sculpture.

C.Choice: The Count paid him to make the sculpture.

D.Choice: The servant broke the original sculpture.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text.
Content: Which event allowed Antonio to sit at the Count’s table?

A.Choice: The statue on the center of the table was stolen.

B.Choice: Antonio’s grandfather was friends with the Count.

C.Choice: The statue to be used for the table centerpiece was broken.

D.Choice: Antonio won a contest and sitting with the Count was the prize.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: What is the reason why “the Count sent for Antonio to come and live with him” the very next day?

A.Choice: He needed to protect Antonio from other artists who were jealous of his skills.

B.Choice: He wanted to provide Antonio with great art teachers to develop his talent.

C.Choice: He hoped to guarantee that Antonio would create sculptures only for him.

D.Choice: He wanted to raise Antonio to be a stonecutter like his grandfather.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which sentence supports the idea that Antonio achieved success?

A.Choice: “ ‘What a beautiful work of art!’ they cried.”

B.Choice: “ ‘Truly, my friends,’ he said, ‘this is as much of a surprise to me as to you.’ ”

C.Choice: “ ‘My name is Antonio Canova,’ said the boy, ‘and I have had no teacher but my grandfather the stonecutter.’

D.Choice: “In a few years, Antonio Canova became known as one of the greatest sculptors in the world.”

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator’s or speaker’s point of view influences how events are described.
Content: What is the narrator’s point of view on the servant breaking the sculpture before the Count’s dinner?

A.Choice: It caused Antonio to show his great talent.

B.Choice: It caused Antonio’s grandfather to lose his job.

C.Choice: It caused the Count to cancel the dinner.

D.Choice: It caused the head servant to get fired.
